body_text.text: SR proteins are sequence-specific RNA-binding factors.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: RNA binding is a requirement for all of their known cellular activities including the spliceosome assembly.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: RNA binding is mediated by the RNA recognition motifs (RRMs) within the N-terminal portions of SR proteins.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: The spliceosome assembly is facilitated by the interaction between the RRMs and exonic splicing enhancers (ESEs) (1,2).
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: The C-terminal RS domain(s) of SR proteins are thought to serve as modifiers of diverse interactions within the spliceosome.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: SRSF1, one of the SR proteins, contains two RRMs at its N-terminus and a relatively short RS domain at the C-terminus.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: The C-terminal RS domain plays a modulatory role in the SRSF1:ESE complex formation through phosphorylation and dephosphorylation of the serine residues (3).
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: The N-terminal RRM-containing region is responsible for sequence-specific RNA binding.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: The more N-terminal RRM (RRM1) exhibits clear sequence similarity to the canonical RRM consensus by virtue of its RNP1 and RNP2 motifs.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: The RRM2 of SRSF1 lacks these motifs.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: SRSF1-specific ESE sequences have been determined by both binding affinity and functional SELEX experiments (4)(5)(6).
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: In addition to selection based and physiological ESE identification, significant progress has been made in identifying ESEs from genome-wide sequences through the use of computational methods (7).
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: All these studies suggest that SRSF1 binds a broad spectrum of ESEs with only a loose consensus among these sequences.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: ESE bound SRSF1 does not only active but also represses splicing.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Other SR proteins also behave similarly as SRSF1 in terms of loose consensus for their respective ESEs and ability to both activate and repress splicing.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: The NMR solution structure of the single-RRM containing SR protein SRSF3 (SRp20) bound to a 4-nt ESE RNA demonstrated that SRSF3 recognizes the ESE in a semi-sequence specific manner by using conserved motifs and amino acid residues within its RRM (8).
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: This mode of ESE recognition by SRSF3 provides some clues as to how numerous degenerate ESE sequences within various pre-mRNA might be recognized by SR proteins.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: RNA-bound structures of non-SR protein splicing factors, Sxl (9), U2AF65 (10), HuD (11) and PTB (12), have also been elucidated.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: In each case, the complex structure contains two RRMs bound to cognate RNA.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: These structures reveal diverse modes by which individual RRMs articulate with one another in recognizing specific target RNA.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: In one case, for example, each RRM of U2AF65 binds to a polypyrimidine tract independent of one another.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: In contrast, the two PTB RRMs recognize their target RNA as a single unit with extensive interdomain protein-protein contacts.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: The Sxl RRMs exhibit clear cooperativity in their binding to RNA.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: In all of these cases the conserved RNP1 and RNP2 motifs are directly involved in RNA recognition.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: The RNA recognition sequences of these splicing factors are highly specific in general.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: However, it is unclear how SR proteins with two RRMs bind to such a large and diverse collection of cognate sequences.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: This study investigates the mechanism of how the SRSF1 RNA-binding domain (RBD) binds to a large repertoire of putative ESEs in cells.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: We found that the protein optimally binds RNA sequences of 10-nt in length with no stringent position-specific base requirement with the exception of uracil.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: The presence of uracils both inside and outside of the recognition sequence is detrimental to binding.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: All three segments of SRSF1, RRM1, RRM2 and the linker are essential for ESE binding.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: The flexibly linked segments in SRSF1 RBD recognize RNA using cooperative interactions.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Our result thus explains how SRSF1 binds to a large number of ESE to promote splicing.

body_text.text: To elucidate the mechanism of ESE RNA recognition by SRSF1, we prepared SRSF1 RBD as a highly purified recombinant protein (Supplementary Figure S1 and Figure 1A).
body_text.section: SRSF1 RBD recognizes ESEs with specificity

body_text.text: We tested the binding affinity of this protein in vitro with the ESEs present in the proto-oncogene Ron (Ron-ESE), which encodes a receptor tyrosine kinase, the breast cancer-associated gene 1 (BRCA1) (BRCA-ESE), and the survival motor neuron protein gene 1 (SMN1) (SMN-ESE) ( Figure 1B).
body_text.section: SRSF1 RBD recognizes ESEs with specificity

body_text.text: In order to investigate the specificity of these ESEs, we also tested binding of the SRSF1 RBD to mutated versions of each of these ESEs.
body_text.section: SRSF1 RBD recognizes ESEs with specificity

body_text.text: The mutant Ron ESE used was tested previously and showed no splicing activity in cells while the naturally occurring BRCA1-ESE and SMN1-ESE mutants have been linked to disease ( Figure 1B) (14)(15)(16).
body_text.section: SRSF1 RBD recognizes ESEs with specificity

body_text.text: A filter-binding (FB) assay was used to evaluate the protein: RNA-binding affinity ( Figure 1C).
body_text.section: SRSF1 RBD recognizes ESEs with specificity

body_text.text: Of the three, the Ron ESE exhibited the highest affinity for SRSF1 RBD.
body_text.section: SRSF1 RBD recognizes ESEs with specificity

body_text.text: However, binding affinity was moderate, measuring in the low micromolar range.
body_text.section: SRSF1 RBD recognizes ESEs with specificity

body_text.text: The BRCA1 and SMN1 ESEs displayed weaker binding affinity.
body_text.section: SRSF1 RBD recognizes ESEs with specificity

body_text.text: As expected, none of the three mutant ESEs showed any detectable binding ( Figure 1C).
body_text.section: SRSF1 RBD recognizes ESEs with specificity

body_text.text: We next tested SRSF1 RBD binding to the 5 0 -SS RNA from the simian virus 40 (SV40) small T antigen (5 0 -SS) as earlier reports suggested its possible involvement in SRSF1 binding ( Figure 1B) (17).
body_text.section: SRSF1 RBD recognizes ESEs with specificity

body_text.text: We found that the SRSF1 RBD exhibits modest binding to 5 0 -SS with an affinity that is similar to the SMN1 ESE ( Figure 1C).
body_text.section: SRSF1 RBD recognizes ESEs with specificity

body_text.text: No interaction was observed when SRSF1 RBD binding to poly-U RNA was assayed as a control ( Figure 1C).
body_text.section: SRSF1 RBD recognizes ESEs with specificity

body_text.text: As an alternative approach, we next ran electrophoretic mobility shift assays (EMSA) to measure the binding affinity of the SRSF1 RBD for Ron ESE and the 5 0 -SS (17) (Supplementary Figure S2A and B).
body_text.section: SRSF1 RBD recognizes ESEs with specificity

body_text.text: EMSA analysis revealed a similar binding pattern as the FB assay with the Ron ESE binding more strongly than 5 0 -SS to the SRSF1 RBD.
body_text.section: SRSF1 RBD recognizes ESEs with specificity

body_text.text: Also in agreement with the FB assay results, the poly-U RNA failed to interact with the protein (Supplementary Figure S2C).
body_text.section: SRSF1 RBD recognizes ESEs with specificity

body_text.text: Therefore, despite their relatively low affinity, SRSF1 RBD binds to ESEs with sequence specificity.
body_text.section: SRSF1 RBD recognizes ESEs with specificity

body_text.text: Even though these 5 0 -SS sequences display some affinity for the SRSF1 RBD, our results do not necessarily imply that SRSF1 binds to these sequences within their natural cellular context.
body_text.section: SRSF1 RBD recognizes ESEs with specificity

body_text.text: Our binding data simply suggest that the 5 0 -SS sequences bear some characteristics of a functional ESE, as predicted by ESEfinder.
body_text.section: SRSF1 RBD recognizes ESEs with specificity

body_text.text: Moreover, we find that binding affinity does not agree with predictions of the ESEfinder scoring system that were developed based upon ESEs identified by functional SELEX method (Figure 1B and C).
body_text.section: SRSF1 RBD recognizes ESEs with specificity

body_text.text: This suggests that SRSF1:ESEbinding affinity and splicing efficiency are not necessarily correlated.
body_text.section: SRSF1 RBD recognizes ESEs with specificity

body_text.text: In order to more clearly define the determinants of SRSF1:ESE binding, we employed the Ron ESE and SRSF1 RBD and investigated their interactions in greater detail.
body_text.section: SRSF1 RBD optimally binds to 10-mer ESE sequences with variable modes

body_text.text: ESE sequences derived from functional SELEX exhibit only modest conservation with natural ESEs through a region of weak consensus that spans only 7 nt (15,18,19).
body_text.section: SRSF1 RBD optimally binds to 10-mer ESE sequences with variable modes

body_text.text: Curiously, in vitro selection for ESEs based solely upon binding affinity identified octameric and decameric consensus sequences (4).
body_text.section: SRSF1 RBD optimally binds to 10-mer ESE sequences with variable modes

body_text.text: To determine whether the SRSF1 RBD binds to RNA sequences that are heptameric or longer, we tested a 13-nt sequence that contained the 7-nt core Ron ESE at the center and uridines nucleotides in all the flanking positions as a 7-mer sequence cannot be efficiently radiolabeled (Figure 2A).
body_text.section: SRSF1 RBD optimally binds to 10-mer ESE sequences with variable modes

body_text.text: FB assay revealed little or no binding of this ESE by SRSF1 RBD ( Figure 2B).
body_text.section: SRSF1 RBD optimally binds to 10-mer ESE sequences with variable modes

body_text.text: Although a negative role for uracils in the flanking regions cannot be eliminated, this result strongly suggested that SRSF1 mediates base-specific contacts with nucleotides beyond the 7-nt consensus core sequence.
body_text.section: SRSF1 RBD optimally binds to 10-mer ESE sequences with variable modes

body_text.text: We next tested several RNA sequences that each contained the 7-nt Ron ESE core sequence and progressively incorporated natural nucleotide sequences at the flanking regions up to the maximum length of 15 nt (Figure 2A).
body_text.section: SRSF1 RBD optimally binds to 10-mer ESE sequences with variable modes

body_text.text: Initially, we tested five different RNA lengths: 7, 9, 11, 13 and 15-nt sequences ( Figure 2B).
body_text.section: SRSF1 RBD optimally binds to 10-mer ESE sequences with variable modes

body_text.text: All of the RNA possessing 11 natural Ron ESE nucleotides or more bound SRSF1 RBD with similar affinities, whereas the 9-nt RNA bound only poorly.
body_text.section: SRSF1 RBD optimally binds to 10-mer ESE sequences with variable modes

body_text.text: These results suggest that the minimal RNA length for native-like Ron ESE:SFRS1 RBD interactions might be 10 or 11 nt.
body_text.section: SRSF1 RBD optimally binds to 10-mer ESE sequences with variable modes

body_text.text: To further define the length of recognition sequence, we generated ESE sequences by adding nucleotide(s) at the 5 0 -end or 3 0 -end of the 9-nt core to create 10L, 10R, 12L, 12R, 14L and 14R ( Figure 2C).
body_text.section: SRSF1 RBD optimally binds to 10-mer ESE sequences with variable modes

body_text.text: Unexpectedly, both 10L and 10R bound the protein with similar affinities and these affinities are comparable to the longer RNA sequences.
body_text.section: SRSF1 RBD optimally binds to 10-mer ESE sequences with variable modes

body_text.text: Sequence comparison of 10L and 10R shows that 6 of 10 positions are different (Figure 2A, bottom).
body_text.section: SRSF1 RBD optimally binds to 10-mer ESE sequences with variable modes

body_text.text: This observation is consistent with the idea that none or only a few base positions within the recognition sequence are stringently fixed to mediate unique interactions with the protein.
body_text.section: SRSF1 RBD optimally binds to 10-mer ESE sequences with variable modes

body_text.text: This mode of binding explains how SRSF1 can accommodate large number of ESE sequences to impose splicing regulation.
body_text.section: SRSF1 RBD optimally binds to 10-mer ESE sequences with variable modes

body_text.text: The failure of binding in the 7-mer core Ron ESE with flanking uracils to protein suggested that the flanking uracils may also play a negative role in the protein-RNA recognition process.
body_text.section: The presence of uracils within or flanking the ESE reduces binding affinity

body_text.text: This observation is further supported by the very low binding affinity of SMN1 and BRCA1 ESEs; both of which contain several Us.
body_text.section: The presence of uracils within or flanking the ESE reduces binding affinity

body_text.text: We further examined the role of uracils within and outside of the core Ron ESE sequence in complex formation with the SRSF1 RBD.
body_text.section: The presence of uracils within or flanking the ESE reduces binding affinity

body_text.text: Having established that a 10-nt sequence is required for full SRSF1 binding, we altered three flanking nucleotides of the 13-nt long Ron-ESE to U (3U) ( Figure 3A).
body_text.section: The presence of uracils within or flanking the ESE reduces binding affinity

body_text.text: Filter-binding assay revealed that the 3U mutant bound with lower affinity to SRSF1 RBD ( Figure 3B).
body_text.section: The presence of uracils within or flanking the ESE reduces binding affinity

body_text.text: Reduced binding by the addition of three Us flanking to the optimized 10-nt sequence suggested that indeed uracils play a negative role in the RNA:protein recognition process.
body_text.section: The presence of uracils within or flanking the ESE reduces binding affinity

body_text.text: It is well established that poly U sequences are highly flexible as uracils are unstacked compared to adenines in poly A ribonucleotide sequences, which undergo temperature-dependent unfolding (20).
body_text.section: The presence of uracils within or flanking the ESE reduces binding affinity

body_text.text: Therefore, the possible explanation for negative role of flanking uracils might arise due to the enhanced flexibility of the core RNA sequence in solution resulting in a greater entropic penalty for the complex formation.
body_text.section: The presence of uracils within or flanking the ESE reduces binding affinity

body_text.text: We further tested whether uracils within ESE sequences affect SRSF1 RBD:ESE complex formation.
body_text.section: The presence of uracils within or flanking the ESE reduces binding affinity

body_text.text: We focused on two positions, 1 and 7, within the core sequence of the Ron ESE ( Figure 3A).
body_text.section: The presence of uracils within or flanking the ESE reduces binding affinity

body_text.text: Previous reports based on functional splicing assays suggested that position 1 prefers C or G and discriminates against U and A, whereas position 7 prefers A or U (5).
body_text.section: The presence of uracils within or flanking the ESE reduces binding affinity

body_text.text: We altered position 1 to either A or U, and position 7 to either U or G and used FB assays to measure the binding affinities of these mutant ESEs for SRSF1.
body_text.section: The presence of uracils within or flanking the ESE reduces binding affinity

body_text.text: We found that, although the presence of U at either of these positions is detrimental to SRSF1 binding, the defect was more severe for U at position 7.
body_text.section: The presence of uracils within or flanking the ESE reduces binding affinity

body_text.text: Although these binding defects might be due to the loss of direct protein:RNA contact(s), or reduced ability of stacking interactions between the protein and uracils, it is also possible that a U at any position within the protein-binding region increases flexibility of ESE, which in turn negatively affects binding.
body_text.section: The presence of uracils within or flanking the ESE reduces binding affinity

body_text.text: In order to investigate the role played by the SRSF1 RBD in ESE recognition, we generated a series of constructs that encompass individual RRM domains alone, RRM1 (R1) and RRM2 (R2), and with the adjacent linker (L), R1L and LR2 ( Figure 4A).
body_text.section: The linker region plays an essential role in ESE binding

body_text.text: Neither R1 (SRSF1 residues 1-90), nor R2, showed any binding to ESE.
body_text.section: The linker region plays an essential role in ESE binding

body_text.text: LR2 (residues 90-196), but not R1L (1-118), showed partial binding ( Figure 4B; Supplementary Figure S3A and B).
body_text.section: The linker region plays an essential role in ESE binding

body_text.text: The respective binding affinities displayed by R1 and LR2 fragments defied the standard RNA-binding norms of RRM as R1, but not R2, contains the RNP motifs.
body_text.section: The linker region plays an essential role in ESE binding

body_text.text: However, the binding affinity of LR2 for ESE was significantly lower when compared to that exhibited by the SRSF1 RBD.
body_text.section: The linker region plays an essential role in ESE binding

body_text.text: Taken together, these results suggest that the linker converts R2 into a RNA-binding motif, and that R1 and LR2 mediate cooperative ESE binding.
body_text.section: The linker region plays an essential role in ESE binding

body_text.text: This conclusion is further supported by the fact that no binding was observed when the linker was deleted.
body_text.section: The linker region plays an essential role in ESE binding

body_text.text: The amino acid composition of the 34-residue long linker indicates it to be highly flexible as it contains 14 glycines.
body_text.section: The linker region plays an essential role in ESE binding

body_text.text: Nine contiguous glycines at the center (G9 segment) separate the two flanking segments containing several arginines interspaced with serines, threonines and tyrosines ( Figure 5A).
body_text.section: The linker region plays an essential role in ESE binding

body_text.text: To further elucidate the role of the SRSF1 linker region in ESE binding, we mutated several residues in both segments of the linker: R90A, R93A, R97A, R109A, R111A, Y112A, S116A, R117A/ R118A and S119A ( Figure 5A).
body_text.section: The linker region plays an essential role in ESE binding

body_text.text: Upon evaluating the SRSF1 RBD mutants by FB assay we found that each was defective for binding to Ron ESE when compared to native SRSF1 RBD ( Figure 5B).
body_text.section: The linker region plays an essential role in ESE binding

body_text.text: The R117A/R118A double mutant showed the most severe defect while both Y112A and S119A single mutants exhibited moderate binding.
body_text.section: The linker region plays an essential role in ESE binding

body_text.text: The remaining mutants showed varying degrees of weakened binding affinity.
body_text.section: The linker region plays an essential role in ESE binding

body_text.text: These observations are consistent with a previous crosslinking-based binding assay that showed defective ESE binding by R117A/R118A mutants in RRM2 construct (107-215) (21).
body_text.section: The linker region plays an essential role in ESE binding

body_text.text: We also examined how the RBD mutants described above affect splicing in S100 splicing complement assay.
body_text.section: The linker region plays an essential role in ESE binding

body_text.text: It was previously shown that RBD alone was able to complement constitutive splicing of b-globin pre-mRNA (3).
body_text.section: The linker region plays an essential role in ESE binding

body_text.text: Therefore, we used the same pre-mRNA in our assay.
body_text.section: The linker region plays an essential role in ESE binding

body_text.text: As expected, wt RBD efficiently complemented splicing; however, none of the linker mutant tested showed any splicing ( Figure 5C).
body_text.section: The linker region plays an essential role in ESE binding

body_text.text: Next, we tested the effect of the F56D/F58D mutant that had been previously shown to be defective in splicing.
body_text.section: The linker region plays an essential role in ESE binding

body_text.text: As expected, this mutant failed to complement splicing in vitro.
body_text.section: The linker region plays an essential role in ESE binding

body_text.text: These results further support the importance of the linker in ESE binding and consequently in splicing.
body_text.section: The linker region plays an essential role in ESE binding

body_text.text: Relatively lesser role of R1 in ESE binding than R2 made us wonder if the most common RNA-binding motif (RNP1), present only in R1 is involved in ESE recognition.
body_text.section: The linker region mediates cooperative binding interactions between ESE and SRSF1-RBD

body_text.text: To examine the role of RNP1 in R1, conserved RNP1 residues, F56 and F58, were mutated to aspartates and the double mutant was tested for ESE binding by FB assay.
body_text.section: The linker region mediates cooperative binding interactions between ESE and SRSF1-RBD

body_text.text: We found that the RBD (F56D/F58D) mutant binds Ron ESE poorly implicating the involvement of these two residues in cognate ESE binding ( Figure 6A).
body_text.section: The linker region mediates cooperative binding interactions between ESE and SRSF1-RBD

body_text.text: This result also explains why the F56D/F58D mutant impairs splicing (22,23).
body_text.section: The linker region mediates cooperative binding interactions between ESE and SRSF1-RBD

body_text.text: Intriguingly, the apparent binding affinity of this RBD mutant is comparable to that of the LR2 fragment suggesting that cooperation between R1 to the rest of the protein in ESE binding is mediated through its conserved RNP1 motif.
body_text.section: The linker region mediates cooperative binding interactions between ESE and SRSF1-RBD

body_text.text: We next investigated how residues in the R2 domain also participate in ESE binding.
body_text.section: The linker region mediates cooperative binding interactions between ESE and SRSF1-RBD

body_text.text: R2 domain does not contain consensus RNP motifs but it includes a conserved heptapeptide sequence SWQDLKD, which has been implicated in RNA binding (21).
body_text.section: The linker region mediates cooperative binding interactions between ESE and SRSF1-RBD

body_text.text: As indicated by the RRM2 structure, W134, Q135 and R154, all reside close to one another on the same positively charged face of R2 (21).
body_text.section: The linker region mediates cooperative binding interactions between ESE and SRSF1-RBD

body_text.text: Therefore, we hypothesized that this face might likely be involved in ESE recognition.
body_text.section: The linker region mediates cooperative binding interactions between ESE and SRSF1-RBD

body_text.text: Although R154A was not defective in ESE binding, the W134A and Q135A mutants exhibited highly defective in ESE binding ( Figure 6A).
body_text.section: The linker region mediates cooperative binding interactions between ESE and SRSF1-RBD

body_text.text: Dramatic defect in ESE binding by these two single mutants suggest cooperation between the protein segments in ESE recognition.
body_text.section: The linker region mediates cooperative binding interactions between ESE and SRSF1-RBD

body_text.text: Moreover, the involvement of four aromatic residues in ESE binding led us to propose that these residues might make stacking interactions as commonly observed in other RNA-protein complexes.
body_text.section: The linker region mediates cooperative binding interactions between ESE and SRSF1-RBD

body_text.text: To further test extensive nature of aromatic-RNA contacts, we mutated four other tyrosines (Y79A and Y82A in R1, Y149A and Y153A in R2) located in the same face as F56/F58 or W134.
